column1: The region's name is derived from its Bagobo origins. The Bagobos were indigenous to the Philippines. The word davao came from the phonetic blending of three Bagobo subgroups' names for the Davao River
column2: a major waterway emptying into the Davao Gulf near the city. The aboriginal Obos
column3: who inhabit the hinterlands of the region
column4: called the river Davah (with a gentle vowel ending
column5: although later pronunciation is with a hard v or b); the Clatta (or Giangan/Diangan) called it Dawaw
column6: and the Tagabawas called it Dabo. To the Obos
column7: davah also means "a place beyond the high grounds" (alluding to settlements at the mouth of the river surrounded by high
column8: rolling hills).

column1: Although the Spaniards began to explore the Davao Gulf area as early as the 16th century
column2: Spanish influence was negligible in the Davao region until 1844
column3: when the Spanish Governor General of the Philippines Narciso Clavería ordered the colonization of the Davao Gulf region
column4: including what is now Davao City
column5: for the Spanish Crown. Despite protests by the Sultan of Maguindanao
column6: official colonization of the area
column7: however
column8: began in 1848 when an expedition of 70 men and women led by José Cruz de Uyanguren of Vergara
column9: Spain
column10: landed on the estuary of the Davao River the same year
column11: intent on colonizing the vicinity. Nearby
column12: a settlement was situated on the banks of the river
column13: ruled by a Muslim Bagobo chieftain named Datu Bago.

column1: Being the strongest chieftain in the region
column2: Datu Bago imposed heavy tribute on the Mandaya tribes nearby
column3: therefore also making him the most loathed chieftain in the region. Cruz de Uyanguren has orders from the higher authorities in Manila to colonize the Davao Gulf region
column4: which included the Bagobo settlement on the northern riverbank. At this juncture

column6: who then ruled Samal Island
column7: came to him
column8: seeking for an alliance against Datu Bago. The two chieftains were archrivals
column9: and Cruz de Uyanguren took advantage of it
column10: initiating an alliance between Spain and the Mandayas of Samal Island. Intent on taking the settlement for Spain
column11: he and his men accordingly assaulted it
column12: but the Bagobo natives fiercely resisted the attacks
column13: which resulted in his Samal Mandaya allies to retreat and not fight again. Thus
column14: a three-month long inconclusive battle for the possession of the settlement ensued which was only decided when an infantry company which sailed its way by warships from Zamboanga came in as reinforcements
column15: thus ensuring the takeover of the settlement and its surroundings by the Spaniards while the defeated Bagobos fled further inland.After Cruz de Oyanguren defeated Bago
column16: he founded the town of Nueva Vergara
column18: on 29 June 1848 in an area of mangrove swamps which is now Bolton Riverside
column19: in honor of his home in Spain and becoming its first governor. Almost two years later on 29 February 1850
column20: the province of Nueva Guipúzcoa was established via a royal decree
column21: with the newly founded town as the capital
column22: once again to honor his homeland in Spain. When he was the governor of the province
column24: his plans of fostering a positive economic sway on the region backfired
column25: which resulted in his eventual replacement under orders of the colonial government.

column1: The province of Nueva Guipuzcoa was dissolved on 30 July 1860
column2: as it became the Politico-Military Commandery of Davao. By the clamor of its natives
column3: a petition was given to the Spanish government to eventually rename Nueva Vergara into Davao
column4: since they have called the town as the latter long from the time of its founding. It was eventually done in year 1867
column5: and the town Nueva Vergara was officially given its present name Davao.The Spanish control of the town was unstable at best
column6: as its Lumad and Moro natives routinely resisted the attempts of the Spanish authorities to forcibly resettle them and convert them into Christians. Despite all these
column7: however

column9: dividing the Christians both settlers and native converts and the Muslim Moros into several religion-based communities within the town.

column2: having been fought for two years

column4: the expected departure of the Spanish authorities in Davao became apparent—although they took no part in the war at all

column6: as the Spanish authorities finally left the town

column1: At the very instant the Americans began their administration of the town in 1900
column2: economic opportunities quickly arose as huge swathes of its areas
column3: mainly lush forests and fertile grasslands
column4: were declared open for agricultural investment. A result of this
column5: foreign businessmen especially Japanese entrepreneurs started settling the region
column6: staking their claims on the vast lands of Davao and turned them into huge plantations of coconut and banana products. In just a short period
column7: Davao changed from a small and sparsely-inhabited town into a bustling economic center serving mainly the Davao Gulf region
column8: heavily populated alongside natives by tens of thousands of settlers and economic migrants from Luzon
column9: Visayas and Japan. All of this led the Port of Davao to be established and opened the same year
column10: in order to facilitate the international export of agricultural products from Davao.

column1: Davao was incorporated as a part of Moro Province from 1903 to 1914. When the province was dissolved in 1914
column2: it led to the establishment of Davao Province
column3: with Davao town as its provincial capital. What is now the city's Legislative Council Building served as the provincial capitol. It was built in 1926
column4: the same year the Davao Municipal Hall
column5: now the City Hall
column6: was constructed.

column1: Because of the rapidly increasing progress of the town
column2: on March 16
column4: congressman Romualdo Quimpo from Davao filed Bill 609 (passed as Commonwealth Act 51)
column5: creating the City of Davao from the town of Davao and the municipal district of Guianga. The bill called for the appointment of local officials by the president. By that time
column6: the new city was already mostly populated with Japanese businessmen and settlers who then became its locals. Davao was inaugurated as a charter city on 16 October 1936 by President Manuel L. Quezon; the charter came into effect on 1 March 1937. It was one of the first two towns in Mindanao to be converted into a city
column7: the other being Zamboanga.

column3: Japanese planes bombed the harbor
column4: and from December 20 they landed forces and began an occupation of the city which lasted to 1945. Davao was among the earliest to be occupied by Japanese forces
column5: and the city was immediately fortified as a bastion of Japanese defense.The city was subjected to extensive bombing by forces led by Douglas MacArthur before American forces landed in Leyte in October 1944. The Battle of Davao towards the end of World War II was one of the longest and bloodiest battles during the Philippine Liberation
column6: and brought tremendous destruction to the city
column7: setting back the economic and physical strides made before the Japanese occupation.

column1: Davao regained its status as the agricultural and economic hub of Mindanao after the war ended in 1945. Wood products such as plywood and timber
column2: and More agricultural products being produced within the city
column3: such as copra and other varieties of banana
column4: became available for export. Some Japanese locals — 80% percent of the city's population prior to the war's end — assimilated with the Filipino population
column5: while others were expelled from the country by the Filipino locals
column6: due to recent enmity.Davao was peaceful and increasingly progressive in the postwar period
column7: including the 1950s and the mid-1960s. Ethnic tensions were minimal
column8: and there was essentially no presence of secessionists groups in Mindanao.In 1967
column9: the Province of Davao was divided into three provinces: Davao del Norte
column10: Davao Oriental and Davao del Sur. The city of Davao became part of Davao del Sur; no longer the provincial capital
column11: it became a commercial center of southern Mindanao. This period also saw the first ever election of an indigenous person to the office of Mayor of Davao City

column2: Martial Law
column3: and the 1980s ===

column1: Things began to take a turn for the worse late into Ferdinand Marcos' first presidential term
column2: when news about the Jabidah massacre ignited a furor in the Moro community
column3: and ethnic tensions encouraged with the formation of secessionist movements. An economic crisis in late 1969 led to social unrest
column4: and violent crackdowns on protests led to the radicalization of many students throughout the country.  With no way to express their grievances about government abuses after the declaration of Martial law in 1972
column5: many of them and joined New People's Army
column6: bringing the Communist rebellion in the Philippines to Davao and the rest of Mindanao for the first time.In the midst of this era
column7: Davao became the regional capital of southern Mindanao; with the reorganization
column8: it became the regional capital of the Davao Region (Region XI) and highly urbanized city in the province of Davao del Sur.

column2: violence in the city became severe as Mindanao became one of the hotbeds of the NPA insurgency. The NPA
column3: too
column4: had became responsible for numerous abuses.  In 1985
column5: locals formed the vigilante group "Alsa Masa" (People's Rise) to counter them.Most Davao residents
column6: however
column7: remained staunchly against violence. This included the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Davao Antonio L. Mabutas
column8: who was among the first religious leaders to peacefully speak out against the Human rights abuses of the Marcos dictatorship. However
column9: these peaceful citizens lacked the political clout to influence the situation much before 1983.This only changed after the  economic crisis of 1983 and the assassination of Ninoy Aquino later that year
column10: and the murder of prominent Davao City journalist Alex Orcullo at a checkpoint in Barangay Tigatto
column12: 1984. These seminal events prompted prominent city figures like Soledad Duterte to organize a protest group called the "Yellow Friday Movement
column13:
which slowly gained support until 1986, when Marcos was finally ousted and forced into exile.Because the local leaders of the time were closely associated with Marcos, they were removed by the 1986 revolutionary government which took power after Marcos' ouster. President Corazon Aquino then appointed Soledad Duterte's son, Rodrigo Duterte, as temporary Vice Mayor of Davao. Rodrigo Duterte later ran for Mayor of Davao City and won, taking the top city office from 1988 to 1998, from 2001 to 2010, and yet again from 2013 to 2016, after which he became President of the Philippines.


== Geography ==
Davao City is approximately 588 miles (946 km) southeast of Manila over land, and 971 kilometres (524 nmi) by sea. The city is located in southeastern Mindanao, on the northwestern shore of Davao Gulf, opposite Samal Island.


=== Topography ===

Davao City's land, totaling about 2,443.61 square kilometres (943.48 sq mi), is hilly in the west (the Marilog district) and slopes down to the southeastern shore. Mount Apo, the highest peak in the Philippines, is located at the city's southwestern tip. Mount Apo National Park (the mountain and its surrounding vicinity), was inaugurated by President Manuel L. Quezon (in Proclamation 59 of May 8, 1936) to protect the flora and fauna of the surrounding mountain range.The Davao River is the city's primary drainage channel. Draining an area of over 1,700 km2 (660 sq mi), the 160-kilometre (99 mi) river begins in the town of San Fernando, Bukidnon. The mouth of the river is located at Barangay Bucana at Talomo District.


=== Climate ===
Davao has a tropical rainforest climate (Köppen climate classification Af), with little seasonal variation in temperature. The areological mechanism of the Intertropical Convergence Zone occurs more often than that of the trade winds and because it experiences rare cyclones the climate is not purely equatorial but subequatorial. Average monthly temperatures are always above 26 °C (78.8 °F), and average monthly rainfall is above 77 millimetres (3.03 in). This gives the city a tropical climate, without a true dry season; while there is significant rainfall in winter, the largest rainfall occurs during the summer months (see climate chart, below).


=== Flora and fauna ===
Mount Apo is home to many bird species, 111 of which are endemic to the area. It is also home to one of the world's largest eagles, the critically endangered Philippine eagle, the country's national bird. The Philippine Eagle Foundation is based near the city. Plant species include the orchid waling-waling, also known as the Queen of Philippine Flowers" as well as one of the country's national flowers
column14: which are also endemic to the area. Fruits such as mangosteen (known as the "queen of fruits") and durian (known as the "king of fruits")

It is projected to surpass Manila's population by 2020 to become the second-largest city in the Philippines.

column1: Davao is connected to other major cities of the Philippines by roll-on/roll-off inter-island ferries. The city is served by domestic passenger ferries at Sasa International Seaport and Santa Ana Wharf
column2: the international seaports of the Port of Davao
column3: the busiest port in Mindanao. The port is capable of servicing inter-island and international shipments. It is located in Davao Gulf and has two approaches
column4: one at Pakiputan Strait between Davao and western Samal Island.

column2: an Aboitiz company which is the third-largest electric utility company in the country

column1: Davao City Water District is the main water supplier in the city. It taps its water supply from the mountain springs in the city's western portion as well as from underground or surface water sources. The city's water supply runs through the company's production wells
column2: sumps and reservoirs within the city. Its biggest water supply system is located at Barangay Dumoy.

column1: Law and order is maintained by the Philippine National Police and a special military group
column2: Task Force (TF) Davao. TF Davao is formed to protect the city from terrorist attacks and other crime and is affiliated with the Philippine Army and headed by an army colonel.A curfew on minors is enforced. All businesses
column3: especially bars and discos
column4: are mandated by a city ordinance to stop selling alcoholic drinks at 1:00 am (Final approval last July 24
column5: 2013). Motorcyclists without helmets and motorists with defective lights are not legally allowed to enter (or drive in) the city. Executive Order No. 39 imposes the reduction of speed limits for all kinds of motor vehicles within the territorial jurisdiction of Davao City.President Rodrigo Duterte
column6: mayor of Davao for 22 years
column7: has been attributed to making Davao into one of the world's safest cities. Rights groups
column8: however
column9: claim that he cites this as justification for his national drug policy. Raw crime data from the Philippine National Police for the years 2010 to 2015 shows that the city had the highest murder rate in the Philippines
column10: and the second highest number of rapes.In February 2018
column11: the Davao City Council officially declared Senator Antonio Trillanes "persona non grata" after Trillanes portrayed the city as the most dangerous in the Philippines and likening Dabawenyos to North Koreans who are easily brainwashed by President Rodrigo Duterte. "Safest city" rankings are often cited from Numbeo
column12: a crowd-sourced survey website; as of February 2018
column13: Davao had dropped to 275th out of 330 cities in Numbeo's "crime index".The Public Safety and Security Command Center (PSSCC)
column16: Matina. It is headquarters for 911 and the center for the 170 closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras installed in different strategic areas as of today covering access roads and populated downtown areas
column17: and also including outside the Davao International Airport and six in different bridges to monitor the rise of water level in the city's rivers. The center also controls traffic signals in the city.In Davao City

column31: Davao City is among the local government units awarded with a "Seal of Good Local Governance" by the Department of the Interior and Local Government. The city was also given the same award in 2015

column1: The Davao Death Squad is a vigilante group supposedly active in Davao City. The group is allegedly responsible for summary executions of street children and individuals suspected of petty crimes and dealing in drugs in Davao. It has been estimated that the group is responsible for the killing or disappearance of between 1
column2: 020 and 1
column3: 040 people between 1998 and 2008. In as early as 2005
column4: the US State Department has received reports of the Human Rights Commission's (HRC) investigation regarding the alleged connection of the Duterte political dynasty of Davao to the killings. This was followed by another investigation in 2009
column5: which was later discontinued. Another investigation by the Office of the Ombudsman was opened and closed in 2019
column6: stating that they found no evidence that the alleged group exists.

column1: The city government provides free education at the primary (grade school) and secondary (high school) levels at public institutions. Currently
column2: as sanctioned by the Department of Education
column3: all primary and secondary institutions in the city use the K-12 educational system. The city currently hosts five universities.
